atsResume.title: Submit resume in PDF or Word? Why format matters for ATS
atsResume.intro: You've spent hours perfecting your resume, but did you know that over 75% of resumes are rejected before a human ever sees them? The culprit? Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS) - and the wrong file format can be your downfall.
atsResume.atsProblemTitle: The ATS Problem: Why Your Resume Gets Lost
atsResume.atsProblemDesc: Applicant Tracking Systems scan your resume to extract information like your name, experience, and skills. Here's the catch: not all file formats are created equal when it comes to ATS compatibility.
atsResume.quickAnswerDesc: Word (.docx) is generally SAFER for ATS systems - but with important exceptions.
atsResume.quickAnswerBullet1: • Use Word (.docx) when the job posting doesn't specify a format
atsResume.quickAnswerBullet2: • Use PDF when explicitly requested or when preserving exact formatting is critical
atsResume.whyWordTitle: Why Word (.docx) Works Better for ATS
atsResume.whyWordPoint1Desc: Word documents store text as plain, structured data. ATS systems can easily parse:
atsResume.whyWordPoint2Desc: Almost all ATS systems (Workday, Taleo, Greenhouse, Lever) can read .docx files without issues.
atsResume.whenPdfFailTitle: When PDFs Fail (And How to Fix It)
atsResume.pdfWarning: Image-based PDFs (scanned documents) are completely unreadable by ATS. Your resume will be auto-rejected.
atsResume.pdfProblem1: Text in headers/footers may be ignored
atsResume.pdfProblem4: Custom fonts may not render correctly
atsResume.convertTitle: Need to Convert? Do It Here (Free, No Sign-up)
atsResume.convertDesc: If you have your resume in the wrong format, don't panic. Convert it right here in seconds:
atsResume.proTip: Pro Tip: After converting, always open the file and check that your formatting stayed intact. Look for missing bullet points, scrambled dates, or misaligned sections.
atsResume.safeStrategyTitle: The Safe Strategy: Submit Both (When Possible)
atsResume.safeStrategyDesc: If the application system allows multiple file uploads:
atsResume.safeStrategy1: 1. Upload .docx as your primary resume (for ATS parsing)
atsResume.safeStrategy2: 2. Upload PDF as a "backup" or in the cover letter section (for human reviewers who want clean formatting)
atsResume.checklist1: ✅ File Format: Use .docx unless PDF is explicitly requested
atsResume.checklist3: ✅ Fonts: Stick to standard fonts (Arial, Calibri, Times New Roman)
atsResume.checklist4: ✅ Layout: Single column, clear headings, no text boxes or images
atsResume.checklist6: ✅ Test It: Open your file in Google Docs to see if text is selectable
atsResume.specificPdfTitle: What If They Specifically Ask for PDF?
atsResume.specificPdfDesc: Some companies (especially in creative fields like design, marketing, or tech startups) prefer PDFs because:
atsResume.specificPdfReason1: • They want to see your exact formatting and design choices
atsResume.specificPdfReason2: • They're using modern ATS systems that handle PDFs well
atsResume.specificPdfReason3: • They value brand presentation and visual consistency
atsResume.specificPdfInstructions: In this case: Always follow their instructions. If they ask for PDF, give them PDF. Use the converter above to switch from Word to PDF if needed.
atsResume.faq1Q: Q: Can I use Google Docs format?
atsResume.faq1A: A: No. Always export to .docx or PDF before submitting. Many ATS systems cannot open Google Docs links or .gdoc files.
atsResume.faq2Q: Q: What about Pages files (.pages) from Mac?
atsResume.faq2A: A: Never submit .pages files. They're only readable on Mac/iOS. Export to .docx or PDF first.
atsResume.faq3Q: Q: Should I password-protect my resume PDF?
atsResume.faq3A: A: Absolutely not. ATS systems cannot open password-protected files. Your application will be auto-rejected.
atsResume.bottomLine1: Default to Word (.docx) for maximum ATS compatibility, but always read the job posting instructions carefully. When in doubt, you can't go wrong with a clean, simple .docx file with standard fonts and single-column layout.
atsResume.bottomLine2: And remember: the converter above is always here, completely free, no email required. Convert as many times as you need until you get it right.
atsResume.goodLuck: Good luck with your job search! The right format is just one piece of the puzzle, but it's an important one that many candidates overlook.

iPhoneVideo.title: Why your iPhone video (HEVC/MOV) won't play on Windows & How to fix it
iPhoneVideo.alertTitle: Frustrated? You just shot a perfect video on your iPhone, transferred it to your Windows PC, and... it won't play. The file is there, but Windows Media Player shows a black screen or error message.
iPhoneVideo.intro: You're not alone. This is one of the most common tech frustrations for iPhone users, and it's not your fault. Here's what's happening and how to fix it permanently.
iPhoneVideo.problemDesc: Since iOS 11 (2017), iPhones record videos using HEVC (High Efficiency Video Coding), also called H.265. This codec:
iPhoneVideo.problemPoint1: ✅ Saves 50% storage space compared to older formats
iPhoneVideo.problemPoint5: ❌ Crashes many video editing programs (Adobe Premiere, DaVinci Resolve, etc.)
iPhoneVideo.whyAppleTitle: Why Apple does this: HEVC is technically superior - smaller files, better quality. But it's patent-encumbered, so Microsoft and Google don't include native support in Windows/Android to avoid licensing fees.
iPhoneVideo.symptomsTitle: Symptoms: How to Know If This Is Your Problem
iPhoneVideo.symptomsDesc: You have the HEVC compatibility issue if:
iPhoneVideo.symptom1: Video file extension is .MOV or .m4v (iPhone's default format)
iPhoneVideo.symptom2: Video plays fine on iPhone/Mac but not on Windows PC
iPhoneVideo.symptom3: Windows Media Player shows "Can't play this file" or codec error
iPhoneVideo.symptom5: Your editing software says "Unsupported codec" or crashes on import
iPhoneVideo.symptom6: When you send the video to Android friends, they can't watch it
iPhoneVideo.officialFixDesc: Microsoft technically offers HEVC codec support, but they charge for it:
iPhoneVideo.officialFixStep4: 4. Hope it works (it often doesn't for older Windows versions)
iPhoneVideo.whySucksPoint1: • It only fixes your computer. Doesn't help if you need to send videos to others.
iPhoneVideo.whySucksPoint3: • You still can't edit the video in many programs.
iPhoneVideo.whySucksPoint4: • It's a band-aid, not a real solution.
iPhoneVideo.realFixTitle: The Real Fix: Convert MOV to MP4 (H.264)
iPhoneVideo.realFixDesc: The permanent solution is to convert your iPhone videos from HEVC to H.264 (standard MP4). This format:
iPhoneVideo.benefit1: Works on every device: Windows, Mac, Linux, Android, smart TVs, game consoles
iPhoneVideo.benefit2: Supported by all editing software: Premiere, Final Cut, DaVinci, iMovie, etc.
iPhoneVideo.benefit3: Easy to share: Works on email, Discord, WhatsApp, social media
iPhoneVideo.benefit4: No quality loss: Modern converters maintain the same visual quality
iPhoneVideo.convertHereTitle: Convert Your iPhone Video Here (Free, No Install)
iPhoneVideo.convertHereDesc: Drag your .MOV file below and select MP4 as the output format. Conversion takes about 1-2 minutes:
iPhoneVideo.technicalNote: Technical Note: This converts HEVC (H.265) to H.264 codec while keeping the MP4 container format. The file size will be slightly larger (about 1.5-2x) but the quality stays identical to human eyes.
iPhoneVideo.preventTitle: Prevent This Problem: Change iPhone Camera Settings
iPhoneVideo.preventDesc: If you frequently transfer iPhone videos to Windows/Android, you can stop this issue from happening in the future:
iPhoneVideo.whatThisDoes: What this does: Your iPhone will now record videos in H.264 (standard MP4) instead of HEVC. Videos will be larger but will work everywhere without conversion.
iPhoneVideo.tradeoffWarning: Trade-off: Video files will be about 2x larger. If you have limited iPhone storage (64GB or less), you might want to keep using HEVC and just convert videos when needed.
iPhoneVideo.commonQ1: Q: Will I lose quality when converting from MOV to MP4?
iPhoneVideo.commonA1: A: No visible quality loss. Modern converters (like this one, which uses FFmpeg) transcode intelligently to preserve quality. The file will be larger, but it will look identical.
iPhoneVideo.commonQ2: Q: Why can't I just rename .MOV to .MP4?
iPhoneVideo.commonA2: A: Because the problem isn't the filename - it's the codec inside. Renaming changes the container but doesn't convert the HEVC video codec to H.264. You need actual conversion.
iPhoneVideo.commonQ3: Q: Can I convert videos shot in 4K or 60fps?
iPhoneVideo.commonA3: A: Yes. All resolutions (1080p, 4K, etc.) and frame rates are supported. The converter preserves your original resolution and frame rate.
iPhoneVideo.commonQ4: Q: Is there a faster way if I have lots of videos?
iPhoneVideo.commonA4: A: For batch conversion, you can use this tool multiple times, or install a desktop app like HandBrake (free, open-source) which can convert multiple files at once.
iPhoneVideo.bottomLine1: Apple prioritizes storage efficiency over compatibility. It's a reasonable choice for the Apple ecosystem, but it creates headaches when you step outside that ecosystem.
iPhoneVideo.bottomLine2: The good news: Converting your videos takes less than 2 minutes and solves the problem permanently. No codecs to buy, no complicated software to learn.
iPhoneVideo.bottomLine3: Just convert your iPhone videos to standard MP4, and they'll work everywhere - Windows, Android, editing software, social media, you name it.
iPhoneVideo.problemSolved: Problem solved! Bookmark this page for next time your iPhone video won't play on Windows. Share it with friends who have the same issue.
